messages.text:
In a Julia Module, if I want to make use of a python library, is this the correct pattern?
First import things in an `__init__()`
```function __init__()
    picamera = pyimport("picamera")
end```
and then in the module you can access that for whatever:
```get_camera() = picamera.PiCamera()```

messages.text: PyCall is wonderful (once you get figured out where the Python code has been loaded and make sure your PyCall is built for that Python environment).  I used it to access all of the  IBM QisKit (quantum computing toolkit) software in no time (it may sound strange, but I felt more comfortable using it through Julia rather than Python, even if there were some minor bumps along the way)

messages.text: `x` in your function is not global but a local variable in `f`. So `x += 1` is increasing a global variable that might not even exist at the beginning.

elements.text: x
in your function is not global but a local variable in
f
. So
is increasing a global variable that might not even exist at the beginning.

messages.text: In your example `x` would be accessible after the loop is run (from outside `f`) and it would be the last value assigned before you stopped the execution with Ctrl-C.

elements.text: In your example
x
would be accessible after the loop is run (from outside
f
) and it would be the last value assigned before you stopped the execution with Ctrl-C.

attachments.fallback:
[December 21st, 2020 8:17 PM] markkitt: Does anyone have an opinion if Julia's `range` ends up taking a distinct path from Python's `range`?

Python current a has `range` defined as either `range(stop)` or `range(start, stop, [step])` where `stop` is not included in the resulting sequence. All arguments have to be integers in Python.

```In [26]: [i for i in range(5)]
Out[26]: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

In [27]: [i for i in range(1,5)]
Out[27]: [1, 2, 3, 4]

In [28]: [i for i in range(1,5,3)]
Out[28]: [1, 4]

In [29]: [i for i in range(1,5,4)]
Out[29]: [1]

In [30]: [i for i in range(1,5,2)]
Out[30]: [1, 3]```
Julia's range current requires keywords to explicitly indicate, `stop`, `length` , or `step`. A proposed change is to adopt a 3-positional argument version of `range(start, stop, length)` which is inclusive of `stop`. These arguments can be any real value.

With some extrapolation:
```julia> range(stop) = 1:stop
range (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> range(start, stop) = start:stop
range (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> range(start, stop, length) = range(start, stop, length = length)
range (generic function with 3 methods)

julia> [i for i in range(5)]
5-element Array{Int64,1}:
 1
 2
 3
 4
 5

julia> [i for i in range(1,5)]
5-element Array{Int64,1}:
 1
 2
 3
 4
 5

julia> [i for i in range(1,5,3)]
3-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 3.0
 5.0

julia> [i for i in range(1,5,4)]
4-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 2.3333333333333335
 3.6666666666666665
 5.0

julia> [i for i in range(1,5,2)]
2-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 5.0```
<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38750>
attachments.text:
Does anyone have an opinion if Julia's `range` ends up taking a distinct path from Python's `range`?

Python current a has `range` defined as either `range(stop)` or `range(start, stop, [step])` where `stop` is not included in the resulting sequence. All arguments have to be integers in Python.

```In [26]: [i for i in range(5)]
Out[26]: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

In [27]: [i for i in range(1,5)]
Out[27]: [1, 2, 3, 4]

In [28]: [i for i in range(1,5,3)]
Out[28]: [1, 4]

In [29]: [i for i in range(1,5,4)]
Out[29]: [1]

In [30]: [i for i in range(1,5,2)]
Out[30]: [1, 3]```
Julia's range current requires keywords to explicitly indicate, `stop`, `length` , or `step`. A proposed change is to adopt a 3-positional argument version of `range(start, stop, length)` which is inclusive of `stop`. These arguments can be any real value.

With some extrapolation:
```julia> range(stop) = 1:stop
range (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> range(start, stop) = start:stop
range (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> range(start, stop, length) = range(start, stop, length = length)
range (generic function with 3 methods)

julia> [i for i in range(5)]
5-element Array{Int64,1}:
 1
 2
 3
 4
 5

julia> [i for i in range(1,5)]
5-element Array{Int64,1}:
 1
 2
 3
 4
 5

julia> [i for i in range(1,5,3)]
3-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 3.0
 5.0

julia> [i for i in range(1,5,4)]
4-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 2.3333333333333335
 3.6666666666666665
 5.0

julia> [i for i in range(1,5,2)]
2-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 5.0```
<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38750>

messages.text:
ok, so the less hacky thing is wrap the thing into a struct.
```mutable struct PyFigure
    o::PyObject
end
f = PyFigure(yourPyObject)
Base.show(io::IOContext, ::MIME{Symbol("image/png")}, f::PyFigure) = f.o."canvas"."print_figure"(io,format="png")
display("image/png",f)```

elements.text: ok, so the less hacky thing is wrap the thing into a struct.

    o::PyObject
end
f = PyFigure(yourPyObject)
Base.show(io::IOContext, ::MIME{Symbol("image/png")}, f::PyFigure) = f.o."canvas"."print_figure"(io,format="png")
display("image/png",f)

messages.text: How does one use PyCall to import from a specific conda environment?

elements.text: How does one use PyCall to import from a specific conda environment?

messages.text: You define the `PYTHON`  environment variable to the location of your conda Python installation and rebuild PyCall.

elements.text: You define the
PYTHON
environment variable to the location of your conda Python installation and rebuild PyCall.

messages.text:
I love Julia's tools for continuous delivery: 1) increment version number 2) `@JuliaRegistrator register`, 3) TagBot does its thing.
My usual Python cycle is: 1) increment version number 2) manually tag release 3) manually build wheels 4) manually upload wheels to PyPi. Julia spoiled me. Does anyone have a nice workflow for continuous delivery for Python packages?

elements.text: I love Julia's tools for continuous delivery: 1) increment version number 2)
@JuliaRegistrator register

, 3) TagBot does its thing.
My usual Python cycle is: 1) increment version number 2) manually tag release 3) manually build wheels 4) manually upload wheels to PyPi. Julia spoiled me. Does anyone have a nice workflow for continuous delivery for Python packages?

messages.text:
Hi all,
What do the cool kids use to build recommender systems in Python these days? I've been asked to advise a colleague at work who's working on a recommender system, but last time I worked on them was 3 years ago and I haven't kept track.
I already know and have used the Surprise library (<http://surpriselib.com/>), but I'm wondering if there's anything interesting I should be looking at (and googling doesn't seem to return much in term of recent stuff).

attachments.title: Home
attachments.text: A simple Python library for building and testing recommender systems.

messages.text:
Python question. What should I use for the following, pybind11? cython? something else? So, I am constructing an assignment for a programming course. What tool should I use for this: end result is to build a python module where there is a short c++ code with some callable functions inside.
1) I want to give the students a short c++-code with some functions defined. I want them in linux to use some easy tool to just create the necessary additional files and directories.
2) they should build the module
3) they should be able to install/import in python3
4) now they modify the c++ code for their purpose, install and run on their data

Assumption is minimal experience with linux.

Ease of use is higher priority than "real-world usefullness"

elements.text:

1) I want to give the students a short c++-code with some functions defined. I want them in linux to use some easy tool to just create the necessary additional files and directories.

3) they should be able to install/import in python3

What’s the best way to install Python on Debian to maximize interop with Julia?
I actually wish to build a docker image for this based on `julia:1.6-buster` and right now it’s using a conda variant. I get warnings with PyJulia and it actually right now doesn’t even work, though it worked a day or two ago.
Poetry look interesting, and I could give it a go, but it needs a Python already installed.
